Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge erred in applying a qualitative test despite sufficient physical presence evidence under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Zhou provided passport stamps, credit card statements, bills, leases, and education records proving 1178 days of physical presence in Canada
Decision_Outcome: Appeal allowed; case remanded for redetermination
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of the Citizenship Judge's decision
Court_Ruling: The Federal Court ruled that when an applicant meets the 1095-day physical presence requirement, a qualitative assessment cannot override it
Defendant_Behavior: Citizenship Judge applied a qualitative test focusing on employment and family ties despite sufficient quantitative evidence
Grounds_for_Claim: Improper application of qualitative test over statutory physical presence requirement
Legal_Standard: Objective measurement of physical presence under s. 5(1)(c)
Assessment_Factor: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal from Citizenship Judgeâ€™s decision to the Federal Court
Credibility_Assessment: Evidence was deemed reliable and sufficient
Evidence_Used: Passport stamps, credit card statements, utility bills, lease agreements, education records
Application_Basis: Meeting the 1095-day physical residency requirement within four years prior to application
Evidence_Assessed: Documentation showing 1178 days of physical presence
Relief_Sought: Allowance of appeal and referral back for proper assessment
Governing_Rule: If the statutory physical presence requirement is met, qualitative factors are not determinative
Outcome: Denial of citizenship set aside; matter referred to another Citizenship Judge
Harm_Assessment: Unlawful denial of a statutory right to citizenship based on incorrect legal interpretation
Cause_Description: Zhou's citizenship application was denied due to alleged failure to meet residency requirements under s. 5(1)(c)
Evidence_Handling: Citizenship Judge improperly disregarded objective evidence of physical presence
Evidence_Issues: Rejection of reliable documentary evidence without justification
Residency_Compliance: 1178 days of physical presence, exceeding the 1095-day threshold
Evidence_Assessment: Objective evidence of physical presence was sufficient and credible
Decision_Rationale: Statutory physical presence requirement was met; qualitative test cannot override it
Evidentiary_Issues: Failure to consider documented proof of residency
Legal_Standard_Applied: Quantitative physical presence test under s. 5(1)(c)
